history.content:
If you "really really want to do wel in 189 and have an A level understanding", you need strong linear algebra and probability background. Its that simple. Don't dish those classes off as "ee classes" because you probably have no clue. 126/127 are essentially math classes that give you background in probability, linear algebra and optimization along with engineering applications, all of which are vital for doing well in 189, which is essentially another math class. Moreover, you haven't taken EE16B as well and you yourself claim that you have forgotten the stuff from Math 54. Sorry if I come off as rude, but not really sure how you expect yourself to have an A level understanding without any specific preparation for 189.

If you're trying to graduate early, remember that that comes with a price. Also, if you ought to do well in 189, I assume it is so that you can further your opportunities in ML. Let me tell you that 126/127/the right background only would help you achieve that.

children.subject: I think I once saw a post by Instructors saying that it's easier (and better) to self-study 189 after taking 126 and 127 than it is to self-study the two EE classes before 189. I am yet to take 189, but I have seen many piazza posts about it because it's one of my end goals here at Berkeley. I would highly recommend that you investigate more on Piazza about people in a similar predicament because the general advice on this matter seems to contradict what you plan to do.

I am self studying ee 127 to build that mathematical foundation needed for 189. Also for 127 I plan on reading the book and doing all the homeworks. This self studying will be the same amount of work I would be putting into the normal course minus the gpa hit as well as stress. I do not plan on continuing with ML for a full fledged career as of now but definitely want to be familiar with it. CS 189 will be harder to self study for me because I know that I will not put in time to do other stuff like projects and what not as well as not dedicate time to learn the ml concepts. I do not see the usefulness of 127 for me other than pure prep for 189 so that is why I am planning on self doing it.

I also have investigated on piazza as well as talked with my friends who did well in all these courses and I keep hearing conflicting opinions. I am taking a heavy courseload already for next semester so desperately fitting in a hard class like 127 to help me prepare for a class I will be taking the following semester doe not seem to be in the best interest when I can take my free time over summer as well as here and there next fall to self study it.

Also I have basically self studied all my courses here. All the lectures are webcasted and hws and solutions and resources are all online. I only want to take 189 in person because I will be forced to internalize all the concepts and material and from what I have heard 127/126 are meant to prepare you for 189 as well as a career in ML. The only downside of this would be that I would not have easy access to a piazza for 127 over summer or OH but I can always sift through the previous semesters piazza or ask friends.
Thanks. I think I’ve decided to self study it over the summer and this fall (do hws and read the book). And over winter break start studying for 189.
Woah, woah. I highly doubt an A- is a bad grade in cs189.

Unpopular opinion here - if Sahai sees this he will definitely not be happy. 

First off - Sahai's usual advice of "take ee126/127 before cs189" is 100% correct. It is wise advice and I agree completely, he is not pulling out of nowhere. There is real value to this and you will definitely get so much more out of cs189 and learn/understand the material more by taking those other courses. Especially with the revamped curriculum this is even more true now than back when I took it. There is real benefit and payoff to learning/understanding the material, it will help you achieve more and make more meaningful contributions. Also cs189 is grueling enough already, taking those other courses will help prepare you. 

The brutally honest flip side is, unfortunately, learning is sometimes not the only priority (or, gasp, even the top priority >_<). As some of my friends sometimes put it, "just putting the 5 characters 'cs189' on your resume" is immensely helpful. The same people in academia and industry who extoll the virtues of the slow route, of taking the background classes first, will not even look at you unless you take cs189. At the same time they will reward bad behavior if you are strong and intelligent enough to get away with it and survive cs189 earlier. Resumes and research are cumulative and the more experience you can stack in the beginning, the further ahead you will get along. If you're trying to go into industry, there's immense pressure to get as much as experience as possible, and if you're trying to go into research or academia, there is immense pressure to publish as much as possible. And the earlier you start either the better. 

I will warn that there are tremendous risks with this "fake it until you make it" approach, and there are real drawbacks to having weak fundamentals and holes in your understanding. It will not help you at all to take cs189 early if you get a bad grade in it (or, to be real here, less than an A. And with the grade inflation in recent semesters, maybe even A+). There is a very real possibility of the entire scheme backfiring terribly on you. But that is par for the course for a shortcut. 

One disclaimer is that clubs like ML@B and other related developments were still in their infancy back in my day, so cs189 might not be as much of a sacred gate as it used to be. But I imagine much of this is still true. 

Ultimately I would still very much recommend Sahai's advice, but out of the honesty from my experience as a student, I would like to put some of the other realities of the situation out there for you to consider as well. It all depends on your priorities, what you want to accomplish, what your limits and constraints are, and your appetite for risk.

Disclaimer: This post is meant to address concerns about going deeper into ML research rather than learning intro ML.

Hi, a lot of the posts on piazza repeatedly always focus on taking on courses as the way to go - I always wanted to address this sort of mentality, but never knew how to put it in words well, so here goes:

I recently just looked over my former childhood stuff just for nostalgia, and these blog posts caught my eye again:

Post 1 Post 2 Post 3

(these are made by a young David Yang with his Putnam Fellow/bunches of papers on algebraic geometry, arguably the one person in our generation who can contend against Terrance Tao's record) - The common bottleneck back in HS was that there were some people who could qualify for this one math olympiad, but suddenly almost everybody fails miserably at the olympiad when it's just 3 problems for 4.5 hours for 2 days. And this wouldn't be solved by teaching everybody more "material" or drilling more common problems, which was a common mistake for improvement. It's not just math olympiads; this bottleneck exists in a lot of activities (chess, gaming, whatever).  

Essentially, he argues the problem with focusing so much on "fundamentals" is that it's not a great indicator of very deep intuition or "larger picture" thinking. Even if you took all of the courses noted above, it doesn't have much of a correlation with someone's ability to read papers "flowingly", or be able to make beautiful connections between subjects. And this has been shown empirically many times, where someone with 10000 A+'s can really falter at making creative ideas, or when a strong physics/biology PhD who has no clue about ML ends up doing a lot of impressive work in ML research when given the opportunity (ex. Google AI Residency) 

I've rarely seen any posts directly giving off this contrary opinion, and I wish there were more, for the sake of having more viewpoints.

history.content:
Has anyone here taken 189 without 126/127. With just lower divs completed? 
Can u comment on ur experiences and if it’s worth waiting another semester to take these ee courses. I want to jump right in as I was planning on graduating early. I really really want to do well in 189 and have an A level understanding but I simply don’t have time or space in my schedule to wait and take the ee courses. 

I have taken all CS lower divs, CS 170, math 54, and ee16a. I did fairly well in them albeit I don’t remember much of Ee16a and 54 since I took them as a freshman. 

Thanks
